question: Let $\mathbf{v} = \begin{bmatrix}3 & -1\end{bmatrix}^T$ and $\alpha = 2$. What is the first component of $\alpha\mathbf{v}$?

answers.feedback: Correct!
Incorrect. Recall that in scalar-vector multiplication, each component of the vector is multiplied by the scalar.

question: Let $\mathbf{v} = \begin{bmatrix}2 & 4 & -1\end{bmatrix}^T$ and $\alpha = -3$. What is the second component of $\alpha\mathbf{v}$?

answers.feedback: Correct!
Incorrect. Recall that in scalar-vector multiplication, each component of the vector is multiplied by the scalar.

question: Let $\mathbf{v} = \begin{bmatrix}-4 & 2\end{bmatrix}^T$ and $\alpha = 0.5$. What is the first component of $\alpha\mathbf{v}$?

answers.feedback: Correct!
Incorrect. Recall that in scalar-vector multiplication, each component of the vector is multiplied by the scalar.

question: Let $\mathbf{v} = \begin{bmatrix}-5 & 0 & 3\end{bmatrix}^T$ and $\alpha = -1$. What is the third component of $\alpha\mathbf{v}$?

answers.feedback: Correct!
Incorrect. Recall that in scalar-vector multiplication, each component of the vector is multiplied by the scalar.
